description: The round payoff this round was 5. You, John chose to play option 2.Kate chose to play option 2. You received a payoff of -5000.

The game is built around a default cooperative (or non‐exploitative) equilibrium where both players choose option 1 and get 0. Because Deepseek-R1’s default is option 1 and it even knows your own default, there’s a strong baseline expectation that both will “play nice” unless one unilaterally deviates.

Deviating from this default (choosing option 2) is a double‐edged sword. If you’re the only one to choose option 2 while your opponent sticks with option 1, you cash in on the round input (a positive gain equal to the round input) and your opponent suffers an equivalent negative payoff. But if both choose option 2, the round input is multiplied by 1000 and both players get a heavy penalty—as happened on 2024‑01‑02 when both picked option 2 and you got –5000 from an input of 5.

The design of the payoff structure, with its extreme punishment for mutual deviation (option 2 by both), implies that even if you’re tempted to "exploit" the opponent’s default behavior, you must weigh the risk that they might also deviate. This creates a situation where the potential for mutual harm is significant, underscoring the need for trust, reliable signaling, or otherwise cautious play when breaking from the default.
